Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Advanced Numerical Simulations of Black Hole Accretion
Award.AbstractNarration:
1. The force of gravity that a black hole exerts is so strong that even light cannot escape. Some black holes form when the core of a star collapses in on itself during a supernova explosion. (A supernova is an exploding star that briefly shines as brightly as the combined light of all the hundreds of billions of stars in an entire galaxy.) Supermassive black holes, with masses millions to billions of times larger than the Sun's may lurk in the centers of most galaxies. A black hole exerts strong tidal forces that can rip apart stars that orbit it too closely. A black hole does not emit radiation itself, but the disruption of a star and infall of the resulting debris both generate considerable energy. Many accreting black hole systems exhibit rapid quasi-periodic oscillations (QPOs). Some produce jets of very high-energy plasma that speed away at velocities close to that of light. The Principal Investigator will use his improved numerical code Cosmos++ to perform simulations of accretion onto black holes. The Intellectual Merit of the proposed research is that it will advance scientists' understanding of black-hole accretion and of the nature of QPOs and properties of jets in such systems. The Broader Impacts include the involvement of students in the research project, as well as the Principal Investigator's participation in various public outreach activities and from the incorporation of his results into classroom lessons.

2. The proposed research will employ the general relativistic magnetohydrodynamics (GRMHD) code Cosmos++ to perform cutting-edge simulations of black hole accretion. The Intellectual Merit of the work is that it will advance astrophysicists' understanding of the differences between viscous and MHD treatments of accretion disks around black holes, of the nature of quasi-periodic oscillations (QPOs) observed in some such systems, and of the orientation of jets in misaligned accretion systems. The Broader Impacts result from the Principal Investigator?s involvement of students in this RUI project, through a variety of public outreach activities, and from the incorporation of his results into his classroom lessons.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During this four-year project, Prof. Fragile and his students used the computational astrophysics simulation code, Cosmos++, to perform numerical studies of black hole accretion. (Accretion is the process by which gas and dust fall onto a central object; it involves an interplay between gravity and angular momentum.) Each simulation was like a virtual experiment, exploring the behavior of these accretion disks under different conditions. The primary goal was to better understand observational phenomena associated with real accretion disks, particularly in systems called black hole X-ray binaries (stellar-mass black holes in close orbit with ordinary stars), although some of the numerical experiments and results were applicable to neutron star systems, tidal disruption events (destruction of a star as it passes too close to a black hole), and accretion onto supermassive black holes.

One of the main highlights of this project was confirming that black hole accretion disks at moderate luminosities are thermally unstable. This longstanding prediction of accretion theory had never before been fully demonstrated in numerical simulations. Prof. Fragile and his students were able to confirm the applicable range of this instability and elucidate observational distinctions between stable and unstable disks.

Another major accomplishment was simulating tidal disruption events, particularly tidal disruption of white dwarf stars by intermediate mass black holes (black holes with masses intermediate between stellar mass and supermassive). Identifying such events in nature could be one way to locate this elusive population of black holes. The simulations by Prof. Fragile's group provide astronomers with clues to be able to distinguish the light curves of such events. They also calculated gravitational wave templates for these events that might used in searches by future gravitational wave observatories.

This grant also allowed Prof. Fragile's groups to study the interaction of Type I X-ray bursts with accretion disks. Type I X-ray bursts are bright flashes of X-ray light produced by runaway thermonuclear fusion on the surface of a neutron star. These X-rays can interact with the surrounding accretion disk, and as Prof. Fragile's research showed, cause dramatic changes in the temperature and surface density of the disk. Such changes must be accounted for in observations that use these bursts to estimate the radius of neutron stars.

The project also provided research experience and STEM training for two graduate students, twelve undergraduates, and one high school student. Students acquired a wide range of skills in high-performance computing, scientific coding, data management and analysis, and technical communication. Additionally, Prof. Fragile and his students participated in a wide range of outreach efforts, doing planetarium shows at local schools, helping with astronomy open house nights, giving public talks through Astronomy on Tap, and serving as astronomy ambassadors during the 2017 Eclipse Across America.
